generalfeedback.text:
If \(u\) and \(v\) are both functions of {@v@} then \[\int u dv = uv - \int v du.\]
Let \(u = {@pp2@}\) and \(dv = {@pp1@} d{@v@}\).
Then \(du = {@diff(pp2,v)@} d{@v@}\) and \(v = {@int(pp1,v)@}\).
So, \[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \int {@p@} d{@v@} &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \int u dv \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle uv - \int v du \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@pp2@}{@int(pp1,v)@} - \int {@int(pp1,v)@}{@diff(pp2,v)@}d{@v@} \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@pp2*int(pp1,v)@} - \int {@int(pp1,v)*diff(pp2,v)@}d{@v@} \end{array}\]
To calculate \[\int {@int(pp1,v)*diff(pp2,v)@}d{@v@}\] we will have to use parts again, by defining
\(u = {@ppp@}\) and \(dv = {@2*pp1/(rdm+1)@}d{@v@}\) so that
\(du = {@diff(ppp,v)@}d{@v@}\) and \(v = {@int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)@}\).
So,
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \int {@int(pp1,v)*diff(pp2,v)@}d{@v@} &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \int u dv \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle uv - \int v du \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@ppp@}{@int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)@} - \int {@int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)@}{@diff(ppp,v)@}d{@v@} \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@ppp*int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)@} - \int {@int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)*diff(ppp,v)@}d{@v@} \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@ppp*int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)-int((int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)*diff(ppp,v)),v)@} + c \end{array}\]
Hence,
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \int {@p@} d{@v@} &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@pp2*int(pp1,v)@} - \int {@int(pp1,v)*diff(pp2,v)@}d{@v@} \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@pp2*int(pp1,v)@} - \left({@ppp*int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)-int((int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)*diff(ppp,v)),v)+c@}\right) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@pp2*int(pp1,v) - (ppp*int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)-int((int(2*pp1/(rdm+1),v)*diff(ppp,v)),v)+c)@} \end{array}\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
